plausible_answers.text: to help sufferers of AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria

plausible_answers.text: basic needs such as nutrition and transportation

qas.question: What did the Gates-funded AIDS program want to ignore?

context: <a0_0>The foundation has donated billions of dollars <b5_0>to help sufferers of AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria<b5_0/><a0_0/>, <a1_0>protecting millions of children from death at the hands of preventable diseases<a1_0/>. However, a 2007 investigation by The Los Angeles Times claimed there are three major unintended consequences with the foundation's allocation of aid. First, sub-Saharan Africa already suffered from a shortage of primary doctors before the arrival of the Gates Foundation, but "by pouring most contributions into the fight against such high-profile killers as AIDS, <a2_0><b8_0>Gates grantees have increased the demand for specially trained, higher-paid clinicians, diverting staff from basic care<b8_0/>" in sub-Saharan Africa<a2_0/>. This "brain drain" adds to the existing doctor shortage and pulls away additional trained staff from children and those suffering from other common killers. Second, <a3_0>"the focus on a few diseases has shortchanged <b6_0>basic needs such as nutrition and transportation<b6_0/><a3_0/>". Third, "Gates-funded vaccination programs have instructed caregivers to ignore – even <a4_0>discourage patients from discussing – <b7_0><b9_0>ailments that the vaccinations cannot prevent<b9_0/><b7_0/>".
